I hope all this has helped educate folks on how this works. Again, I know there will be lots of disagreements, but I don't like it when there is misinformation--sometimes deliberate misinformation. Let's set aside conspiracy theories and personal attacks, and have a great debate
Also....36 pct of 12 seeds have won their first game, and 21 pct of 13 seeds. On the show today, I'll look to pick 1-2 No. 12 seed to win at least one game, and at least one No. 13 seed.

Over the last 20 tourneys, 60 pct of Final Four teams have been 1 seeds. 32 pct have been 2s, and 18 pct have been seeded 5 or below. So safest strategy is pick two 1 seeds to go to the Final Four, one 2, and one sleeper 5 or lower.
As for picking games, lots to cover next few days, but here are some stats courtesy of CBS ace researcher Wayne Fidelman.
Again: Disagree with their decisions all you want. I'm sure I will. But it's not because the results didn't count. Capisce?
And btw it's not just the teams playing that are impacted. All those dominoes get tipped. So a team from the Mountain West that was set for New York might get switched to Vegas.

For many years now (I'm not sure exactly how long), the committee has done a half dozen-plus contingency brackets to account for today's games. There are two games going on right now. They affect the seed ranking marginally, but it could be a big difference in bracketing.

The NET replaced the RPI because the RPI was purely results based. The NET is results based but features predictive properties like those used on KenPom etc. The NET is designed to be correct on Selection Sunday, when all the data is in.
Lots of misconceptions about the NET. It is an organizing tool. A team's overall rank is not all that important. It's reflective of what's important, but the rank itself means nothing.

First off, deciding the teams. Much of this is subjective. But most is not. The idea is to standardize the committe's decisions as much as possible. The final bracket will look very much like most of the mock brackets out there. Some differences, yes, but a lot more similarities
We're about two and a half hours from seeing the bracket. So let's talk about the bracket and how it's put together.

The unofficial start to March Madness is a 43-year-old TV program. CBS gets the completed brackets 15-60 minutes in advance to prepare for analysis and create graphics. But once the full slate is released, chaos ensues. @MMcCarthyREV and @achristovichh on Selection Sunday »
Another common misconception: there is no S curve. It’s all based on geography.
